title: How is a DVD-9 different from a DVD? - Quora

response.answer_text: How is a DVD-9 different from a DVD? and by “DVD-9” I’m assuming that you mean a dual layer DVD with a 8.5GB capacity. These DVDs have multiple layers that can be burned, given a recording drive capable of doing dual layers rather than the single layer, 4.7GB DVD drives that were initially realeased. Most (all?) drives can read properly recorded dual layer discs (I’ve never had an issue reading commercially burned dual layer discs on a read only DVD (computer) drive. By way of example, here is an (desktop) internal Sony DL (Dual Layer) burner for sale on the “New Egg” web site: SONY DVD±RW (±R DL) drive SATA Model 5280S-CB-ROBOT - Newegg.com. for for $155. A portable version, e.g. if you’re Laptop oriented LG SP80NB80 Portable DVD-Writer - DVD-RAM/±R/±RW Support - 24x CD Read/24x CD Write/24x CD Rewrite - 8x DVD Read/8x DVD Write/8x DVD Rewrite - Double-layer Media Supported - USB - Sl - Newegg.com for $48 (also on New Egg). note that even if they say DVD in the title and it’s only $20–30, the burner may be able to READ DVD but only burns CDs… or READ DL DVD, it can only write SL DVD. Now, for what its worth (FWIW), the same architecture applies to Blu-ray SL is 25GB, Dual Layer (DL) is 50GB but the discs are more expensive (and they’ve been out there for a while. But they’ll write DL DVD as well as CDs… Here is an external LG burner from Best Buy: https://www.bestbuy.com/site/lg-6x-external-blu-ray-disc-double-layer-dvdrw-cd-rw-drive-black/6162900.p While this is not what you asked, given the incremental price difference, you may find it worth considering. Good Luck.

A DVD-9 has two data layers on it, one underneath the other. The laser on the drive reading it changes its wavelength to read the second layer, such that the beam will pass through the outer layer, and bounce off pits in the lower one. The total storage capacity is around 8 to 8.5 GB, depending on how it is formatted. A single layer DVD is known as a DVD-5, and can hold roughly 4.2 to 4.7 GB. As a general rule, the first sign of failing optical components in a drive is when it has trouble reading the inner layer of a double layer disc.
